In Search of God''s Love
Our Responsibility to seek God''s Love:
One can only imagine the weight of responsibility that Moroni felt as he
saw that the Nephite kingdom was about to be destroyed. He wrote
words that he knew would lay hidden in the ground for centuries, and
wrote them lovingly for a people he had only seen in prophetic
vision. Yet knowing that the eternal impact of his words would be
tremendous, he wrote to our generation in great anxiety of heart. One
need only imagine oneself in Moroni''s position. What would be
the words we would write to our posterity, having seen them, knowing
their hearts, and having seen their desires? And how would we
conclude our words, knowing that they would be the last not only to
fall from our pen, but would be the final monument to the thousand
year documentation of the spiritual lives of a great people? More
immediately, what would we tell our children as they knelt beside our
death bed? What would be the last words that fell from our mouths-the
words that would matter most, and would ring in the ears of our
children throughout their lives?
Moroni concludes his work, and the work of a millennium of his ancestors,
with the following admonitions: "Yea, come unto Christ, and be
perfected in him, and deny yourselves of all ungodliness; and if ye
shall deny yourselves of all ungodliness, and love God with all your
might, mind and strength, then is his grace sufficient for you, that
by his grace ye may be perfect in Christ; and if by the grace of God
ye are perfect in Christ, ye can in nowise deny the power of God. And
again, if ye by the grace of God are perfect in Christ, and deny not
his power, then are ye sanctified in Christ by the grace of God,
through the shedding of the blood of Christ, which is in the covenant
of the Father unto the remission of your sins, that ye become holy,
without spot.
And now I bid unto all, farewell. I soon go to rest in the paradise of
God, until my spirit and body shall again reunite, and I am brought
forth triumphant through the air, to meet you before the pleasing bar
of the great Jehovah, the Eternal Judge of both quick and dead.
Amen." Moroni 10:32-34
Moroni''s concluding words are what I refer to as "Holographic
Verse". A hologram is a three dimensional picture of some
object. Its special properties allow it to contain in every tiny
picture element, information about the entire image. If a painting of
a rose were torn into bits, we''d have many pieces that depicted
various parts of a rose. One bit may show a fragment of stem, another
a thorn, another some background, or a petal, or a vase, etc. Alone
any element would be insufficient to show us that the original
painting had been of a single rose. If a holographic rendering of a
rose were dashed to pieces, however, we''d have innumerable
fragments that all represent the entire rose, seen from a particular
point of view. One fragment may be a representation as if we viewed
the flower from above, another from one side, etc. Moroni''s
final words contain a near complete blue-print for God''s plan
for our happiness. Like a hologram, this complete picture of
salvation is viewed from a particular vantage point-a Nephit prophet
near the end of his life, writing to a people who wouldn''t be
born for over 1,500 years, but a complete view. Distilled into
it''s basic elements, the view of God''s plan for us is as
follows:
1- Be perfected in Christ, including overcoming sinfulness
2- Love God
3- Through obedience and God''s love (which may a synonym for the
commonly used word "Grace"), we''re sanctified, or made
holy, through the blood of Christ, or his atonement
4- A reuniting will occur-a resurrection-- joining the body and spirit,
and in this resurrected body we''ll join the ones we love.
Note in the above formula the role that love plays. Throughout history
man has tried to reach heaven through his works. The ancient
Babylonians built a tower to reach God, their Hebrew brothers created
intricate and confusing laws, and among every infidel people there
seems to have arise some distortion of the law of sacrifice, as if
this alone would justify us in our sins.
At the other end of the Book of Mormon, almost 1,000 years earlier,
another prophet explains the simple and pure formula by which Eternal
Life is achieved: "Wherefore, ye must press forward with a
steadfastness in Christ, having a perfect brightness of hope, and a
love of God and of all men. Wherefore, if ye shall press forward,
feasting upon the word of Christ, and endure to the end, behold, thus
saith the Father: Ye shall have eternal life.

And now, behold, my beloved brethren, this is the way; and there is none
			other way nor name given under heaven whereby man can be saved in the

by which men may stand in the presence of their Eternal Father. And
we may ask, how has this requirement been established? Surely God
loves us. This is plain and manifest throughout the scriptures. But
why has he placed such a premium on our returned love for him, and by
extension, on our love of our fellow men?

In his letter to the Galatians, Paul breaks the hologram of the plan of
salvation into even smaller pieces, and holding up one tiny fragment
distils all the law and the prophets into a single word: "For
all the law is fulfilled in one word, even in this; Thou shalt love
thy neighbour as thyself." Galatians5:14 Now many consider that
this law of love is a product of Christ''s mortal ministry, and
is only found in the New Testament. Yet the law of love was clearly
given to the Israelites on Mount Sinai. The very first of the 10
commandments, "Thou shalt have no other gods before me", is
a clear command to love God. In the Book of Deuteronomy (a word
translated as "the repeated law", indicating that the
people had heard it earlier) we read: "And thou shalt love the
LORD thy God with all thine heart, and with all thy soul, and with
all thy might." (Deuteronomy6:5).
Like Moroni''s holographic fragment of the plan of Salvation, the
Israelites are given the same plan: "And now, Israel, what doth
the LORD thy God require of thee, but to fear the LORD thy God, to
walk in all his ways, and to love him, and to serve the LORD thy God
with all thy heart and with all thy soul, To keep the commandments of
the LORD, and his statutes, which I command thee this day for thy
good?" Deut10:12,13 The formula:
1- Fear God (a synonym for loving Him)
2- Obey his commandments and serve Him
After 40 years of wandering in the wilderness, and after the Lord had
either destroyed or allowed to expire from old age the original host
of Israel which had fled Egypt, but which couldn''t leave her
behind, it was time to enter the promised land. Standing at the brink
of their promised blessing, the younger, and now softer hearted host
of Israel were once again instructed of the Lord as to those things
that would be required of them to posses and retain this great
blessing. Moses exhorts, "Hear, O Israel: The LORD our God is
one LORD: And thou shalt love the LORD thy God with all thine heart,
and with all thy soul, and with all thy might." Deut 6: 4,5
To Joseph Knight Sr., the Lord clearly taught, "And no one can
assist in this work except he shall be humble and full of love,
having faith, hope, and charity, being temperate in all things,
whatsoever shall be entrusted to his care." D&C12:8
Sacrifice
The willful exchange of something we acknowledge has earthly value for
something that we hope has eternal value.
There is no righteous sacrifice that doesn''t lead us directly to the
atonement of the Savior. From the firstlings of the flock to a
grateful payment of tithing, all righteous sacrifice leads us to the
great and final sacrifice-final not because man would never be asked
to give again, but because it is the only sacrifice that will have
power to break the bands of death.

any understanding of God''s love-how he has manifested it for us,
and how we find it in our own hearts to share with others.

Perhaps the most condemning words ever spoken of a man were those
spoken by Joseph Smith of his friend, companion, and fellow disciple,
Sidney Rigdon. The Prophet said, "Brother Sidney is a man whom I
love, but he is not capable of that pure and steadfast love for those
who are his benefactors that should characterize a President of the
Church of Christ." (Joseph Fielding Smith, Church History and
Modern Revelation, 4 vols. [Salt Lake City: The Church of Jesus
Christ of Latter-day Saints, 1946-1949], 3: 7.)
Sidney Rigdon''s faults echo of the man Paul describes to the
Corinthians: "Though I speak with the tongues of men and of
angels, and have not charity, I am become as sounding brass, or a
tinkling cymbal. And though I have the gift of prophecy, and
understand all mysteries, and all knowledge; and though I have all
faith, so that I could remove mountains, and have not charity, I am
nothing. And though I bestow all my goods to feed the poor, and
though I give my body to be burned, and have not charity, it
profiteth me nothing." (1Corinthians 13:1-3). Indeed, the early
history of the Church was replete with those who would willingly
sacrifice time, comfort, worldly things, even their own lives, but
who did so without the pure and steadfast love-charity-which Joseph
describes here.

Charity or Pure Love defined:
The Apostle Paul defines Charity thusly: "Charity suffereth long,
and is kind; charity envieth not; charity vaunteth not itself, is not
puffed up,
Doth not behave itself unseemly, seeketh not her own, is not easily
provoked, thinketh no evil; Rejoiceth not in iniquity, but rejoiceth
in the truth; Beareth all things, believeth all things, hopeth all
things, endureth all things." (1 Corinthians 13:4-7)
Moroni, perhaps quoting from the same ancient text as Paul, or inspired by
the same spirit, gives much the same definition of Charity, and then
defines it in its simplest terms: "And again, behold I say unto
you that he cannot have faith and hope, save he shall be meek, and
lowly of heart. If so, his faith and hope is vain, for none is
acceptable before God, save the meek and lowly in heart; and if a man
be meek and lowly in heart, and confesses by the power of the Holy
Ghost that Jesus is the Christ, he must needs have charity; for if he
have not charity he is nothing; wherefore he must needs have charity.
And charity suffereth long, and is kind, and envieth not, and is not
puffed up, seeketh not her own, is not easily provoked, thinketh no
evil, and rejoiceth not in iniquity but rejoiceth in the truth,
beareth all things, believeth all things, hopeth all things, endureth
all things. Wherefore, my beloved brethren, if ye have not charity,
ye are nothing, for charity never faileth. Wherefore, cleave unto
charity, which is the greatest of all, for all things must fail-But
charity is the pure love of Christ, and it endureth forever; and
whoso is found possessed of it at the last day, it shall be well with
him." (Moroni7:43-47).
Charity, purely and simply defined, is the pure love of Christ. The ancient
prophets knew it. The Modern prophets have known it. Godly men and
women have known and embraced this solemn truth.

Making Charity Happen
In his April 2002 General Conference address, Elder Gene R. Cook makes
the following recommendations to those who would see to find charity
in their lives:
1. Recognize His love. "Pray . . . with all the energy of
heart" for this gift. Do so in meekness with a broken heart, and
you will be filled with hope and love from the Holy Ghost Himself. He
will reveal Christ to you.
2. Receive His love in humility. Be grateful for the gift and
especially for the giver of the gift. True gratitude is the ability
to humbly see, feel, and even receive love. Gratitude is a form of
returning love to God. Recognize His hand, tell Him so, express your
love to Him. As you come to truly know the Lord, you will find an
intimate, sacred relationship built on trust. You will come to know
He understands your anguish and will, in compassion, always respond
to you in love.
3. Convey His love. The Lord''s response to us is always filled
with love. Should not our response to Him be in kind, with real
feelings of love? He gives grace (or goodness) for grace, attribute
for attribute. As our obedience increases, we receive more grace (or
goodness) for the grace we return to Him. Offer Him the refinement of
your attributes, so that when He does appear you will be like Him.

Fear
The word "fear" seems to denote different things in different
parts of the scriptures. Where it refers to man''s relationship
with Diety, however, the word often suggests deep love and respect as
opposed to terror or distrust. The basis of the word
fear, in any context, is subjugation or acknowledgement
of inferiority. A person''s fear of high places, for example, is
an acknowledgement that the consequences of a misstep from such a
place will be beyond ones'' control. Such can be said of other
fears or phobias-they derive from an acknowledgement of inferiority
to a superior force, imagined or real.
Man therefore fears God when man is humble enough to admit to himself
that there''s a greater power in the Universe than himself. As
inevitable as the consequences of natural laws such as gravity or
darkness, God''s laws have consequences. The basis of our
fear of God is humility. Unlike other natural laws,
however, our understanding of heavenly laws grows from an
understanding that they''re based on a plan to make us happy. The
sinner may be brought to fear God as he feels remorse for his sins,
and realizes that eternal misery awaits him as a consequence. But
this fear, or distrust of God (as if he were an assailant) quickly
grows within the humbled sinner''s heart as it changes to a fear,
or love for God who has prepared a plan of repentance and forgiveness
of sin.
Consider King Benjamin''s great sermon to his people:
Mosiah 5:1 "And now, it came to pass that when king Benjamin had made
an end of speaking the words which had been delivered unto him by the
angel of the Lord, that he cast his eyes round about on the
multitude, and behold they had fallen to the earth, for the fear of
the Lord had come upon them." In this verse one could easily
infer that the people, reminded of their own sinful ways, had fallen
to the earth because, having seen their own filthiness, they
literally doubted, and therefore feared, that they would be able to
gain a celestial reward. Their fall to the ground would in this
context have been as the victim before the assailant, trembling and
begging for mercy.
This thought continues in the next verse: 2 "And they had viewed
themselves in their own carnal state, even less than the dust of the
earth. And they all cried aloud with one voice, saying: O have
mercy…" Here we might imagine our helpless, groveling victim.
But then our perspective changes as the people explain that they have
great hope, even knowledge, that something better awaits them:

.and apply the atoning blood of Christ that we may receive
			forgiveness of our sins, and our hearts may be purified; for we
			believe in Jesus Christ, the Son of God, who created heaven and
			earth, and all things; who shall come down among the children of
			men. The people, having understood God''s love for them,
fell to the ground in full faith that they would receive a remission
of their sins through the atoning blood of Christ.
This being said, there''s value in rereading the first verse of
Mosiah 5, now substituting the word "fear" with the idea of
its intended synonym, "God''s love". We read, "And
now, it came to pass that when king Benjamin had made an end of
speaking the words which had been delivered unto him by the angel of
the Lord, that he cast his eyes round about on the multitude, and
behold they had fallen to the earth, for the [love] of the Lord had
come upon them." Perhaps the salient question is this: Do the
Lord''s children respond more meaningfully and powerfully through
the repellent force of a distrustful fear of their Father, or from a
humble and respectful love of the same?
We can substitute this word "love" for "fear" in
many other verses of scripture. To the children of Israel, wandering
dependently in the wilderness for 40 years, Moses asks, "And
now, Israel, what doth the LORD thy God require of thee, but to fear
the LORD thy God, to walk in all his ways, and to love him, and to
serve the LORD thy God with all thy heart and with all thy soul, To
keep the commandments of the LORD, and his statutes, which I command
thee this day for thy good?" Deut10:12,13 We note in this verse
the juxtaposition of the commandments to both fear and love the Lord.

As I was pondering love today, the following quote caught my attention:
Love established in the home then extends out to the neighborhood,
the state, the nation, and the world and has the power to bind people
together and make them one. "Differences of language, of
education, of race and of nationality all disappear. Under its
influence, prejudices and animosities vanish" (Cannon, George Q.
Gospel Truth p. 299). This comes out of the encyclopedia of Mormonism

and that differences of language will disappear with love. Applying

A Book of Mormon Tour of Godly Love
This tour explores the Book of Mormon as a historical field guide, of
sorts, into the understanding of Godly Love. Through every chapter, I
suppose, there are references, either overtly or implied, that
demonstrate Godly Love, or the consequences of those who choose to
turn away from the Lord.
1 Nephi 1:1 "I, Nephi, having been born of goodly parents,
therefore I was taught somewhat in all the learning of my father; and
having seen many afflictions in the course of my days, nevertheless,
having been highly favored of the Lord in all my days; yea, having
had a great knowledge of the goodness and the mysteries of God,
therefore I make a record of my proceedings in my days."
Nephi begins his first narrative in the Book of Mormon, which becomes the
first chapter and verse, by describing the love of parents to
children, the importance of educating them, the reality of
afflictions in all of our lives, and the blessings which come as we
overcome our afflictions, having faith in God, and learning of His
ways. It begins with open gratitude to his acknowledged Heavenly
Father for great gifts. It begins with a Godly man, standing within
himself, yet looking beyond himself:
· Acknowledgement of Parents
· Importance of education
· Overcoming adversity
· Gratitude to the Lord
· Learning of the Lord
· Importance of record keeping
In fact, the first verse of the Book of Mormon becomes, as it were, a
type and a shadow for the rest of the book. It also becomes a
synopsis of what it means to experience Godly Love. This love of a
Heavenly Father begins in the love of earthly parents who teach and
nourish us, and moves on to how we use our earthly blessings to bless
others.
Within a few verses we come to understand the context of the people who
would be known as the Nephites-a people born in a tumultuous time in
the history of Israel-a people who would either leave to escape the
onslaught of the Babylonians, or who would be conquered and carried
away by them. And here we find the man Lehi, blessed by the Lord and
prospering in earthly ways, yet focused outside of himself.
1 Nephi 1:5. "Wherefore it came to pass that my father, Lehi, as
he went forth prayed unto the Lord, yea, even with all his heart, in
behalf of his people." We''ve journeyed only 5 verses into
the Book of Mormon and we''ve learned the order of love-God to
his children, children to fathers, and now, man to his brother-the
human family. It''s not enough to speak of God''s love for
us, but rather, we must speak of God''s love in us, or through
us-we being the mirror that immediately reflects God''s light
onto our brethren.
In his vision, Lehi is handed a book of scripture to read, and as he
reads, he''s "filled with the Spirit of the Lord." (1
Nephi 1:12). We now come upon another synonym for "God''s
Love", which is "the Spirit of the Lord". If we
literally accept the Biblical Pronouncement by the Apostle John that
God is love (1 John 4:8), we can use the terms God and
Love interchangeably. To say that Lehi is filled with the Spirit of
the Lord is equal to saying he is filled with the Spirit of Love. In
this way each person who feels the Spirit of the Lord recognizes this
love in is/her life. John elaborates: "Beloved, let us love one
another: for love is of God; and every one that loveth is born of
God, and knoweth God." (1 John 4:7) Being filled with this
Spirit, or in other words, this Love, it''s no surprise to learn
what Lehi does next. His heart is turned inside out, as he looks from
self to his fellow men, and jeapordizes his life to go out and preach
among them. His heart is filled with gratitude as he turns to the
lord and exclaims, "Great and marvelous are thy works, O Lord
God Almighty! Thy throne is high in the heavens, and thy power, and
goodness, and mercy are over all the inhabitants of the earth; and,
because thou art merciful, thou wilt not suffer those who come unto
thee that they shall perish!" (1 Nephi 1:14) This godly mercy of
which Lehi speaks is another synonym for the idea of God''s love.
Nephi explains, "But behold, I, Nephi, will show unto you that
the tender mercies of the Lord are over all those whom he hath
chosen, because of their faith, to make them mighty even unto the
power of deliverance." (1 Nephi 1:20)
As Lehi continues to be faithful in the charge he''s received to
warn his fellow men, we read the following: "For behold, it came
to pass that the Lord spake unto my father, yea, even in a dream, and
said unto him: Blessed art thou Lehi, because of the things which
thou hast done; and because thou hast been faithful and declared unto
this people the things which I commanded thee, behold, they seek to
take away thy life." 1 Nephi 2:1 This great man has put away
personal considerations and fears (pride) to do the will of the Lord,
and for this he''s "blessed". We may well ask, what
does it mean to be "blessed"? Webster''s 1828
Dictionary defines the term, in part, as "enjoying spiritual
happiness and the favor of God; enjoying heavenly felicity".
This definition is quite insightful. Note that the term doesn''t
express as much what God has given his children, but rather, their
recognition and acknowledgement of those gifts. In other words, we
might well ask, "to whom has the Lord denied gifts that would
bring them back to him?" What child of God is their upon this
earth whom the Lord has denied those spiritual and temporal gifts
that would allow him/her to return to their Heavenly Father? The
answer, quite simply, is none. Every soul born upon this earth was
already one of the elect-a victor in the War in Heaven. Every soul is
born with the same destiny to return and live in a Heavenly Home,
For there is no respect of persons with God. Romans 2:11
The blessed man or woman, therefore, isn''t that soul who has
received the greatest amount from God, but rather, is that person who
recognizes God''s gifts in his/her life. The blessed soul
isn''t he who has received most, for we all receive according to
our capacity to receive. The blessed soul is that which recognizes
God''s love and His gifts.
Consider the Beatitudes in this context (Matthew 5:3-13):
· Blessed are the poor in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
· Blessed are they that mourn: for they shall be comforted.
· Blessed are the meek: for they shall inherit the earth.
· Blessed are they which do hunger and thirst after righteousness: for
they shall be filled.
· Blessed are the merciful: for they shall obtain mercy.
· Blessed are the pure in heart: for they shall see God.
· Blessed are the peacemakers: for they shall be called the children
of God.
· Blessed are they which are persecuted for righteousness'' sake:
for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
· Blessed are ye, when men shall revile you, and persecute you, and
shall say all manner of evil against you falsely, for my sake.
Rejoice, and be exceeding glad: for great is your reward in heaven:
for so persecuted they the prophets which were before you.
In each case, a person is recognized as blessed, not for something the
Lord has given them, but for something they''ve given back to the
Lord. In each case the person is blessed who has submitted to the
will of the Father (is poor in spirit, mourns, is meek, hungers after
righteousness, is merciful, pure in heart, a peacemaker, is
persecuted for righteousness'' sake, suffers for the Lord).
He''s blessed first for what he has submitted himself to, and
he''s promised blessings afterwards for the consequence of his
choice (obtains the kingdom of heaven, is comforted, inherits the
earth, is filled, obtains mercy, sees God, is called a Child of God,
obtains the kingdom of heaven, receives a great reward in Heaven.)
Thus, when the Lord pronounces Lehi blessed for his selfless actions,
we might wonder about this-he must abandon riches, and any reputation
among men he may have had. He must leave the comfort of a luxurious
home, and take an often-rebellious family into the wilderness to be
deprived of a lifestyle many would argue he''d earned. But
he''s blessed for who he is, having submitted to God''s will,
feeling God''s love in his life. Lehi is "blessed"
during the sacrifices he makes, because through these righteous acts
of submission to God''s will, he feels God''s love.
Conversely, we might add that any act of self-deprivation that
doesn''t allow us to feel God''s love at the moment of
submission probably isn''t a "blessing" to us.
We''re only blessed in sacrifice as it draws us closer to God and
allows us to feel his love for and through us.
So Lehi draws his family together, and in willing submission to
God''s will, leaves the comfortable life he knew, and departs
into the wilderness. We know that some of his family has gone through
the process to believe, and walks with him in faith. Nephi prays, and
receives a steady answer that his father has indeed been instructed
of the Lord. Lehi receives the vision, and Nephi confirms it through
prayer. Then Nephi bears testimony to his brother Sam, who, through
Nephi''s faith and testimony, gains testimony of the same. But
Laman and Lemuel are unwilling to submit themselves-unwilling to
believe. "And thus Laman and Lemuel, being the eldest, did
murmur against their father. And they did murmur because they knew
not the dealings of that God who had created them." (1Nephi2:12)
They "knew not the dealings…of God." In other words, they
were unfamiliar with his ways, with his intercession with his
children, and with his love for them. What faith could they possibly
have in a being whom they hadn''t come to know. What courage
would they be able to draw as they left all of their comforts, that
they''d continue to be happy and watched over? For Nephi, the
journey into the wilderness was relatively simple. His journey was
governed by a single great principle, for he did know the dealings of
God. He knew that at all times, and in every moment, through every
hardship and trial, he was loved by the only being in the Universe
who''s feelings really matter.
We learn from the writings of the prophet Joseph Smith, that

Faith, then, is the first great governing principle which has
			power, dominion, and authority over all things; by it they exist, by
			it they are upheld, by it they are changed, or by it they remain,
			agreeable to the will of God. (Lectures on Faith, 1:24.) What
is faith, then, if not the understanding that God loves us, and seeks
the best for us? To exercise faith, then, is simply a matter of
trust, that the Lord will seek out the best for us, and is, in all
ways, empowered to deliver it to us. Nephi and Lehi had this faith
through vision, Sam and Sariah had it through their willingness to be
counseled by Lehi and Nephi. But Laman and Lemuel rejected the
Lord''s overtures of love, and thus knew now his workings.
For Nephi, it wasn''t sufficient to gain a testimony of the Gospel
of Jesus Christ. He wanted to learn more. He wanted to understand the
mysteries of God, which I suppose, simply means those
things that are revealed to an individual through study and prayer.
He records, "And it came to pass that I, Nephi, being
exceedingly young, nevertheless being large in stature, and also
having great desires to know of the mysteries of God, wherefore, I
did cry unto the Lord; and behold he did visit me, and did soften my
heart that I did believe all the words which had been spoken by my
father; wherefore, I did not rebel against him like unto my
brothers." 1 Nephi 2:16 Why did Nephi need to soften his heart,
and what exactly does the phrase mean? We know that the term has
something to do with humility, and something to do with being
teachable.
The commandment Lehi received to leave all their worldly wealth and go
to some unseen promised land would have been difficult to obey. But
for his sons, the commandment to return to their former home, collect
all of their abandoned wealth, then take it to a man they greatly
feared in exchange for something which had little earthly value-this
was a true test. Lehi sent his sons, Laman, Lemuel, Sam and Nephi
back to Jerusalem to fetch the records of their fathers-a genealogy
and scripture. In this moment Nephi provides one of the most quoted
and illuminating verses of scripture in his simple statement,

And it came to pass that I, Nephi, said unto my father: I will
			go and do the things which the Lord hath commanded, for I know that
			the Lord giveth no commandments unto the children of men, save he
			shall prepare a way for them that they may accomplish the thing which
			he commandeth them. 1 Nephi 3:7
This simple statement, when distilled to it''s essential elements,
states,
I WILL BEGIN.
When they return, it falls upon Laman to convince Laban to give them the
plates. But Laban is angered by Laman''s suggestion, throws him
out, and tries to have him killed. The young men consult, and Laman
and Lemuel are certain they''ve done everything that was expected
of them. They went back, gave it their best try, and now, they
presume, stand guiltless before their father. But again, the young
Nephi, in Godly wisdom, says: "But behold I said unto them that:
As the Lord liveth, and as we live, we will not go down unto our
father in the wilderness until we have accomplished the thing which
the Lord hath commanded us." 1 Nephi 3:15
When we distill this simple statement to its essential elements, we hear,
I WILL ENDURE
A new plan to take all of their precious things to exchange for the
plates of Laban fails miserably as well, and not only is the gold and
silver taken from them, but they''re pursued by the armies of
Laban who have been sent to kill them. Once again Laman and Lemuel
confront Nephi, this time striking him with a rod, and once again
Nephi persists, "And it came to pass that I spake unto my
brethren, saying: Let us go up again unto Jerusalem, and let us be
faithful in keeping the commandments of the Lord; for behold he is
mightier than all the earth, then why not mightier than Laban and his
fifty, yea, or even than his tens of thousands?" 1 Nephi 4:1
It''s not enough to have tried once, or to have risked everything
and tried again. Nephi''s statement would seem insane to anyone
who doesn''t understand the relationship of the Lord with his
children. But Nephi''s eye is set, not on the waves of a
turbulent sea, as Peter was one fateful evening, but on the love of
his God. His simple statement above concisely affirms,
WE (the Lord through me) WILL SUCCEED.
To feel God''s love is to understand he cannot fail us-we can only
fail him. To have God''s love is to look beyond earthly obstacles
and acknowledge that so long as we''re involved in His work,
we''ll have His strength, and His protection.
Then, in this marvelous, faithful journey to follow the will of the Lord,
submitting all desires to the Lord, and finally, submitting all
fears, Nephi states, "And I was led by the Spirit, not knowing
beforehand the things which I should do." 1 Nephi 4:6. In this
simple testimony of faith the young believer simply states,

In Search of God''s Love
Our Responsibility to seek God''s Love:
One can only imagine the weight of responsibility that Moroni felt as he
saw that the Nephite kingdom was about to be destroyed. He wrote
words that he knew would lay hidden in the ground for centuries, and
wrote them lovingly for a people he had only seen in prophetic
vision. Yet knowing that the eternal impact of his words would be
tremendous, he wrote to our generation in great anxiety of heart. One
need only imagine oneself in Moroni''s position. What would be
the words we would write to our posterity, having seen them, knowing
their hearts, and having seen their desires? And how would we
conclude our words, knowing that they would be the last not only to
fall from our pen, but would be the final monument to the thousand
year documentation of the spiritual lives of a great people? More
immediately, what would we tell our children as they knelt beside our
death bed? What would be the last words that fell from our mouths-the
words that would matter most, and would ring in the ears of our
children throughout their lives?
Moroni concludes his work, and the work of a millennium of his ancestors,
with the following admonitions: "Yea, come unto Christ, and be
perfected in him, and deny yourselves of all ungodliness; and if ye
shall deny yourselves of all ungodliness, and love God with all your
might, mind and strength, then is his grace sufficient for you, that
by his grace ye may be perfect in Christ; and if by the grace of God
ye are perfect in Christ, ye can in nowise deny the power of God. And
again, if ye by the grace of God are perfect in Christ, and deny not
his power, then are ye sanctified in Christ by the grace of God,
through the shedding of the blood of Christ, which is in the covenant
of the Father unto the remission of your sins, that ye become holy,
without spot.
And now I bid unto all, farewell. I soon go to rest in the paradise of

Moroni''s concluding words are what I refer to as "Holographic
Verse". A hologram is a three dimensional picture of some
object. Its special properties allow it to contain in every tiny
picture element, information about the entire image. If a painting of
a rose were torn into bits, we''d have many pieces that depicted
various parts of a rose. One bit may show a fragment of stem, another
a thorn, another some background, or a petal, or a vase, etc. Alone
any element would be insufficient to show us that the original
painting had been of a single rose. If a holographic rendering of a
rose were dashed to pieces, however, we''d have innumerable
fragments that all represent the entire rose, seen from a particular
point of view. One fragment may be a representation as if we viewed
the flower from above, another from one side, etc. Moroni''s
final words contain a near complete blue-print for God''s plan
for our happiness. Like a hologram, this complete picture of

As I was pondering love today, the following quote caught my attention:
Love established in the home then extends out to the neighborhood,
the state, the nation, and the world and has the power to bind people
together and make them one. "Differences of language, of
education, of race and of nationality all disappear. Under its
influence, prejudices and animosities vanish" (Cannon, George Q.
Gospel Truth p. 299). This comes out of the encyclopedia of Mormonism
under "love". The reference to language is what struck me,
and that differences of language will disappear with love. Applying
this to the Tower of Babel I can''t help but wonder if what
caused the collapse of the unified language was indeed the

love. Is this where the gift of tongues derives-this Godly love? How
else can it be explained?
A Book of Mormon Tour of Godly Love
This tour explores the Book of Mormon as a historical field guide, of
sorts, into the understanding of Godly Love. Through every chapter, I
suppose, there are references, either overtly or implied, that
demonstrate Godly Love, or the consequences of those who choose to
turn away from the Lord.
1 Nephi 1:1 "I, Nephi, having been born of goodly parents,
therefore I was taught somewhat in all the learning of my father; and
having seen many afflictions in the course of my days, nevertheless,
having been highly favored of the Lord in all my days; yea, having
had a great knowledge of the goodness and the mysteries of God,
therefore I make a record of my proceedings in my days."
Nephi begins his first narrative in the Book of Mormon, which becomes the
first chapter and verse, by describing the love of parents to
children, the importance of educating them, the reality of
afflictions in all of our lives, and the blessings which come as we
overcome our afflictions, having faith in God, and learning of His
ways. It begins with open gratitude to his acknowledged Heavenly
Father for great gifts. It begins with a Godly man, standing within
himself, yet looking beyond himself:
· Acknowledgement of Parents
· Importance of education
· Overcoming adversity
· Gratitude to the Lord
· Learning of the Lord
· Importance of record keeping
In fact, the first verse of the Book of Mormon becomes, as it were, a
type and a shadow for the rest of the book. It also becomes a
synopsis of what it means to experience Godly Love. This love of a
Heavenly Father begins in the love of earthly parents who teach and
nourish us, and moves on to how we use our earthly blessings to bless
others.
Within a few verses we come to understand the context of the people who
would be known as the Nephites-a people born in a tumultuous time in
the history of Israel-a people who would either leave to escape the
onslaught of the Babylonians, or who would be conquered and carried
away by them. And here we find the man Lehi, blessed by the Lord and
prospering in earthly ways, yet focused outside of himself.
1 Nephi 1:5. "Wherefore it came to pass that my father, Lehi, as
he went forth prayed unto the Lord, yea, even with all his heart, in
behalf of his people." We''ve journeyed only 5 verses into
the Book of Mormon and we''ve learned the order of love-God to
his children, children to fathers, and now, man to his brother-the
human family. It''s not enough to speak of God''s love for
us, but rather, we must speak of God''s love in us, or through
us-we being the mirror that immediately reflects God''s light
onto our brethren.
In his vision, Lehi is handed a book of scripture to read, and as he
reads, he''s "filled with the Spirit of the Lord." (1
Nephi 1:12). We now come upon another synonym for "God''s
Love", which is "the Spirit of the Lord". If we
literally accept the Biblical Pronouncement by the Apostle John that
God is love (1 John 4:8), we can use the terms God and
Love interchangeably. To say that Lehi is filled with the Spirit of
the Lord is equal to saying he is filled with the Spirit of Love. In
this way each person who feels the Spirit of the Lord recognizes this
love in is/her life. John elaborates: "Beloved, let us love one
another: for love is of God; and every one that loveth is born of
God, and knoweth God." (1 John 4:7) Being filled with this
Spirit, or in other words, this Love, it''s no surprise to learn
what Lehi does next. His heart is turned inside out, as he looks from
self to his fellow men, and jeapordizes his life to go out and preach
among them. His heart is filled with gratitude as he turns to the
lord and exclaims, "Great and marvelous are thy works, O Lord
God Almighty! Thy throne is high in the heavens, and thy power, and
goodness, and mercy are over all the inhabitants of the earth; and,
because thou art merciful, thou wilt not suffer those who come unto
thee that they shall perish!" (1 Nephi 1:14) This godly mercy of
which Lehi speaks is another synonym for the idea of God''s love.
Nephi explains, "But behold, I, Nephi, will show unto you that
the tender mercies of the Lord are over all those whom he hath
chosen, because of their faith, to make them mighty even unto the
power of deliverance." (1 Nephi 1:20)
As Lehi continues to be faithful in the charge he''s received to
warn his fellow men, we read the following: "For behold, it came
to pass that the Lord spake unto my father, yea, even in a dream, and
said unto him: Blessed art thou Lehi, because of the things which
thou hast done; and because thou hast been faithful and declared unto
this people the things which I commanded thee, behold, they seek to
take away thy life." 1 Nephi 2:1 This great man has put away
personal considerations and fears (pride) to do the will of the Lord,
and for this he''s "blessed". We may well ask, what
does it mean to be "blessed"? Webster''s 1828
Dictionary defines the term, in part, as "enjoying spiritual
happiness and the favor of God; enjoying heavenly felicity".
This definition is quite insightful. Note that the term doesn''t
express as much what God has given his children, but rather, their
recognition and acknowledgement of those gifts. In other words, we
might well ask, "to whom has the Lord denied gifts that would
bring them back to him?" What child of God is their upon this
earth whom the Lord has denied those spiritual and temporal gifts
that would allow him/her to return to their Heavenly Father? The
answer, quite simply, is none. Every soul born upon this earth was
already one of the elect-a victor in the War in Heaven. Every soul is
born with the same destiny to return and live in a Heavenly Home,
For there is no respect of persons with God. Romans 2:11
The blessed man or woman, therefore, isn''t that soul who has
received the greatest amount from God, but rather, is that person who
recognizes God''s gifts in his/her life. The blessed soul
isn''t he who has received most, for we all receive according to
our capacity to receive. The blessed soul is that which recognizes
God''s love and His gifts.
Consider the Beatitudes in this context (Matthew 5:3-13):
· Blessed are the poor in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
· Blessed are they that mourn: for they shall be comforted.
· Blessed are the meek: for they shall inherit the earth.
· Blessed are they which do hunger and thirst after righteousness: for
they shall be filled.
· Blessed are the merciful: for they shall obtain mercy.
· Blessed are the pure in heart: for they shall see God.
· Blessed are the peacemakers: for they shall be called the children
of God.
· Blessed are they which are persecuted for righteousness'' sake:
for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
· Blessed are ye, when men shall revile you, and persecute you, and
shall say all manner of evil against you falsely, for my sake.
Rejoice, and be exceeding glad: for great is your reward in heaven:
for so persecuted they the prophets which were before you.
In each case, a person is recognized as blessed, not for something the
Lord has given them, but for something they''ve given back to the
Lord. In each case the person is blessed who has submitted to the
will of the Father (is poor in spirit, mourns, is meek, hungers after
righteousness, is merciful, pure in heart, a peacemaker, is
persecuted for righteousness'' sake, suffers for the Lord).
He''s blessed first for what he has submitted himself to, and
he''s promised blessings afterwards for the consequence of his
choice (obtains the kingdom of heaven, is comforted, inherits the
earth, is filled, obtains mercy, sees God, is called a Child of God,
obtains the kingdom of heaven, receives a great reward in Heaven.)
Thus, when the Lord pronounces Lehi blessed for his selfless actions,
we might wonder about this-he must abandon riches, and any reputation
among men he may have had. He must leave the comfort of a luxurious
home, and take an often-rebellious family into the wilderness to be
deprived of a lifestyle many would argue he''d earned. But
he''s blessed for who he is, having submitted to God''s will,
feeling God''s love in his life. Lehi is "blessed"
during the sacrifices he makes, because through these righteous acts
of submission to God''s will, he feels God''s love.
Conversely, we might add that any act of self-deprivation that
doesn''t allow us to feel God''s love at the moment of
submission probably isn''t a "blessing" to us.
We''re only blessed in sacrifice as it draws us closer to God and
allows us to feel his love for and through us.
So Lehi draws his family together, and in willing submission to
God''s will, leaves the comfortable life he knew, and departs
into the wilderness. We know that some of his family has gone through
the process to believe, and walks with him in faith. Nephi prays, and
receives a steady answer that his father has indeed been instructed
of the Lord. Lehi receives the vision, and Nephi confirms it through
prayer. Then Nephi bears testimony to his brother Sam, who, through
Nephi''s faith and testimony, gains testimony of the same. But
Laman and Lemuel are unwilling to submit themselves-unwilling to
believe. "And thus Laman and Lemuel, being the eldest, did
murmur against their father. And they did murmur because they knew
not the dealings of that God who had created them." (1Nephi2:12)
They "knew not the dealings…of God." In other words, they
were unfamiliar with his ways, with his intercession with his
children, and with his love for them. What faith could they possibly
have in a being whom they hadn''t come to know. What courage
would they be able to draw as they left all of their comforts, that
they''d continue to be happy and watched over? For Nephi, the
journey into the wilderness was relatively simple. His journey was
governed by a single great principle, for he did know the dealings of
God. He knew that at all times, and in every moment, through every
hardship and trial, he was loved by the only being in the Universe
who''s feelings really matter.
We learn from the writings of the prophet Joseph Smith, that

Faith, then, is the first great governing principle which has
			power, dominion, and authority over all things; by it they exist, by
			it they are upheld, by it they are changed, or by it they remain,
			agreeable to the will of God. (Lectures on Faith, 1:24.) What
is faith, then, if not the understanding that God loves us, and seeks
the best for us? To exercise faith, then, is simply a matter of
trust, that the Lord will seek out the best for us, and is, in all
ways, empowered to deliver it to us. Nephi and Lehi had this faith
through vision, Sam and Sariah had it through their willingness to be
counseled by Lehi and Nephi. But Laman and Lemuel rejected the
Lord''s overtures of love, and thus knew now his workings.
For Nephi, it wasn''t sufficient to gain a testimony of the Gospel
of Jesus Christ. He wanted to learn more. He wanted to understand the
mysteries of God, which I suppose, simply means those
things that are revealed to an individual through study and prayer.
He records, "And it came to pass that I, Nephi, being
exceedingly young, nevertheless being large in stature, and also
having great desires to know of the mysteries of God, wherefore, I
did cry unto the Lord; and behold he did visit me, and did soften my
heart that I did believe all the words which had been spoken by my
father; wherefore, I did not rebel against him like unto my
brothers." 1 Nephi 2:16 Why did Nephi need to soften his heart,
and what exactly does the phrase mean? We know that the term has
something to do with humility, and something to do with being
teachable.
The commandment Lehi received to leave all their worldly wealth and go
to some unseen promised land would have been difficult to obey. But
for his sons, the commandment to return to their former home, collect
all of their abandoned wealth, then take it to a man they greatly
feared in exchange for something which had little earthly value-this
was a true test. Lehi sent his sons, Laman, Lemuel, Sam and Nephi
back to Jerusalem to fetch the records of their fathers-a genealogy
and scripture. In this moment Nephi provides one of the most quoted
and illuminating verses of scripture in his simple statement,

And it came to pass that I, Nephi, said unto my father: I will
			go and do the things which the Lord hath commanded, for I know that
			the Lord giveth no commandments unto the children of men, save he
			shall prepare a way for them that they may accomplish the thing which
			he commandeth them. 1 Nephi 3:7
This simple statement, when distilled to it''s essential elements,
states,
I WILL BEGIN.
When they return, it falls upon Laman to convince Laban to give them the
plates. But Laban is angered by Laman''s suggestion, throws him
out, and tries to have him killed. The young men consult, and Laman
and Lemuel are certain they''ve done everything that was expected
of them. They went back, gave it their best try, and now, they
presume, stand guiltless before their father. But again, the young
Nephi, in Godly wisdom, says: "But behold I said unto them that:
As the Lord liveth, and as we live, we will not go down unto our
father in the wilderness until we have accomplished the thing which
the Lord hath commanded us." 1 Nephi 3:15
When we distill this simple statement to its essential elements, we hear,
I WILL ENDURE
A new plan to take all of their precious things to exchange for the
plates of Laban fails miserably as well, and not only is the gold and
silver taken from them, but they''re pursued by the armies of
Laban who have been sent to kill them. Once again Laman and Lemuel
confront Nephi, this time striking him with a rod, and once again
Nephi persists, "And it came to pass that I spake unto my
brethren, saying: Let us go up again unto Jerusalem, and let us be
faithful in keeping the commandments of the Lord; for behold he is
mightier than all the earth, then why not mightier than Laban and his
fifty, yea, or even than his tens of thousands?" 1 Nephi 4:1
It''s not enough to have tried once, or to have risked everything
and tried again. Nephi''s statement would seem insane to anyone
who doesn''t understand the relationship of the Lord with his
children. But Nephi''s eye is set, not on the waves of a
turbulent sea, as Peter was one fateful evening, but on the love of
his God. His simple statement above concisely affirms,
WE (the Lord through me) WILL SUCCEED.
To feel God''s love is to understand he cannot fail us-we can only
fail him. To have God''s love is to look beyond earthly obstacles
and acknowledge that so long as we''re involved in His work,
we''ll have His strength, and His protection.
Then, in this marvelous, faithful journey to follow the will of the Lord,
submitting all desires to the Lord, and finally, submitting all
fears, Nephi states, "And I was led by the Spirit, not knowing
beforehand the things which I should do." 1 Nephi 4:6. In this
simple testimony of faith the young believer simply states,

In Search of God''s Love
Our Responsibility to seek God''s Love:
One can only imagine the weight of responsibility that Moroni felt as he
saw that the Nephite kingdom was about to be destroyed. He wrote
words that he knew would lay hidden in the ground for centuries, and
wrote them lovingly for a people he had only seen in prophetic
vision. Yet knowing that the eternal impact of his words would be
tremendous, he wrote to our generation in great anxiety of heart. One
need only imagine oneself in Moroni''s position. What would be
the words we would write to our posterity, having seen them, knowing
their hearts, and having seen their desires? And how would we
conclude our words, knowing that they would be the last not only to
fall from our pen, but would be the final monument to the thousand
year documentation of the spiritual lives of a great people? More
immediately, what would we tell our children as they knelt beside our
death bed? What would be the last words that fell from our mouths-the
words that would matter most, and would ring in the ears of our
children throughout their lives?
Moroni concludes his work, and the work of a millennium of his ancestors,
with the following admonitions: "Yea, come unto Christ, and be
perfected in him, and deny yourselves of all ungodliness; and if ye
shall deny yourselves of all ungodliness, and love God with all your
might, mind and strength, then is his grace sufficient for you, that
by his grace ye may be perfect in Christ; and if by the grace of God
ye are perfect in Christ, ye can in nowise deny the power of God. And
again, if ye by the grace of God are perfect in Christ, and deny not
his power, then are ye sanctified in Christ by the grace of God,
through the shedding of the blood of Christ, which is in the covenant
of the Father unto the remission of your sins, that ye become holy,
without spot.
And now I bid unto all, farewell. I soon go to rest in the paradise of
God, until my spirit and body shall again reunite, and I am brought
forth triumphant through the air, to meet you before the pleasing bar
of the great Jehovah, the Eternal Judge of both quick and dead.
Amen." Moroni 10:32-34
Moroni''s concluding words are what I refer to as "Holographic
Verse". A hologram is a three dimensional picture of some
object. Its special properties allow it to contain in every tiny
picture element, information about the entire image. If a painting of
a rose were torn into bits, we''d have many pieces that depicted
various parts of a rose. One bit may show a fragment of stem, another
a thorn, another some background, or a petal, or a vase, etc. Alone
any element would be insufficient to show us that the original
painting had been of a single rose. If a holographic rendering of a
rose were dashed to pieces, however, we''d have innumerable
fragments that all represent the entire rose, seen from a particular
point of view. One fragment may be a representation as if we viewed
the flower from above, another from one side, etc. Moroni''s
final words contain a near complete blue-print for God''s plan
for our happiness. Like a hologram, this complete picture of
salvation is viewed from a particular vantage point-a Nephit prophet
near the end of his life, writing to a people who wouldn''t be
born for over 1,500 years, but a complete view. Distilled into
it''s basic elements, the view of God''s plan for us is as
follows:
1- Be perfected in Christ, including overcoming sinfulness
2- Love God
3- Through obedience and God''s love (which may a synonym for the
commonly used word "Grace"), we''re sanctified, or made
holy, through the blood of Christ, or his atonement
4- A reuniting will occur-a resurrection-- joining the body and spirit,
and in this resurrected body we''ll join the ones we love.
Note in the above formula the role that love plays. Throughout history
man has tried to reach heaven through his works. The ancient
Babylonians built a tower to reach God, their Hebrew brothers created
intricate and confusing laws, and among every infidel people there
seems to have arise some distortion of the law of sacrifice, as if
this alone would justify us in our sins.
At the other end of the Book of Mormon, almost 1,000 years earlier,
another prophet explains the simple and pure formula by which Eternal
Life is achieved: "Wherefore, ye must press forward with a
steadfastness in Christ, having a perfect brightness of hope, and a
love of God and of all men. Wherefore, if ye shall press forward,
feasting upon the word of Christ, and endure to the end, behold, thus

understanding that they''re based on a plan to make us happy. The

A Book of Mormon Tour of Godly Love
This tour explores the Book of Mormon as a historical field guide, of
sorts, into the understanding of Godly Love. Through every chapter, I
suppose, there are references, either overtly or implied, that
demonstrate Godly Love, or the consequences of those who choose to
turn away from the Lord.
1 Nephi 1:1 "I, Nephi, having been born of goodly parents,
therefore I was taught somewhat in all the learning of my father; and
having seen many afflictions in the course of my days, nevertheless,
having been highly favored of the Lord in all my days; yea, having
had a great knowledge of the goodness and the mysteries of God,
therefore I make a record of my proceedings in my days."
Nephi begins his first narrative in the Book of Mormon, which becomes the
first chapter and verse, by describing the love of parents to
children, the importance of educating them, the reality of
afflictions in all of our lives, and the blessings which come as we
overcome our afflictions, having faith in God, and learning of His
ways. It begins with open gratitude to his acknowledged Heavenly
Father for great gifts. It begins with a Godly man, standing within
himself, yet looking beyond himself:
· Acknowledgement of Parents
· Importance of education
· Overcoming adversity
· Gratitude to the Lord
· Learning of the Lord
· Importance of record keeping
In fact, the first verse of the Book of Mormon becomes, as it were, a
type and a shadow for the rest of the book. It also becomes a
synopsis of what it means to experience Godly Love. This love of a
Heavenly Father begins in the love of earthly parents who teach and
nourish us, and moves on to how we use our earthly blessings to bless
others.
Within a few verses we come to understand the context of the people who
would be known as the Nephites-a people born in a tumultuous time in
the history of Israel-a people who would either leave to escape the
onslaught of the Babylonians, or who would be conquered and carried
away by them. And here we find the man Lehi, blessed by the Lord and
prospering in earthly ways, yet focused outside of himself.
1 Nephi 1:5. "Wherefore it came to pass that my father, Lehi, as
he went forth prayed unto the Lord, yea, even with all his heart, in
behalf of his people." We''ve journeyed only 5 verses into
the Book of Mormon and we''ve learned the order of love-God to
his children, children to fathers, and now, man to his brother-the
human family. It''s not enough to speak of God''s love for
us, but rather, we must speak of God''s love in us, or through
us-we being the mirror that immediately reflects God''s light
onto our brethren.
In his vision, Lehi is handed a book of scripture to read, and as he
reads, he''s "filled with the Spirit of the Lord." (1
Nephi 1:12). We now come upon another synonym for "God''s
Love", which is "the Spirit of the Lord". If we
literally accept the Biblical Pronouncement by the Apostle John that
God is love (1 John 4:8), we can use the terms God and
Love interchangeably. To say that Lehi is filled with the Spirit of
the Lord is equal to saying he is filled with the Spirit of Love. In
this way each person who feels the Spirit of the Lord recognizes this
love in is/her life. John elaborates: "Beloved, let us love one
another: for love is of God; and every one that loveth is born of
God, and knoweth God." (1 John 4:7) Being filled with this
Spirit, or in other words, this Love, it''s no surprise to learn
what Lehi does next. His heart is turned inside out, as he looks from
self to his fellow men, and jeapordizes his life to go out and preach
among them. His heart is filled with gratitude as he turns to the
lord and exclaims, "Great and marvelous are thy works, O Lord
God Almighty! Thy throne is high in the heavens, and thy power, and
goodness, and mercy are over all the inhabitants of the earth; and,
because thou art merciful, thou wilt not suffer those who come unto
thee that they shall perish!" (1 Nephi 1:14) This godly mercy of
which Lehi speaks is another synonym for the idea of God''s love.
Nephi explains, "But behold, I, Nephi, will show unto you that
the tender mercies of the Lord are over all those whom he hath
chosen, because of their faith, to make them mighty even unto the
power of deliverance." (1 Nephi 1:20)
As Lehi continues to be faithful in the charge he''s received to
warn his fellow men, we read the following: "For behold, it came
to pass that the Lord spake unto my father, yea, even in a dream, and
said unto him: Blessed art thou Lehi, because of the things which
thou hast done; and because thou hast been faithful and declared unto
this people the things which I commanded thee, behold, they seek to
take away thy life." 1 Nephi 2:1 This great man has put away
personal considerations and fears (pride) to do the will of the Lord,
and for this he''s "blessed". We may well ask, what
does it mean to be "blessed"? Webster''s 1828
Dictionary defines the term, in part, as "enjoying spiritual
happiness and the favor of God; enjoying heavenly felicity".
This definition is quite insightful. Note that the term doesn''t
express as much what God has given his children, but rather, their
recognition and acknowledgement of those gifts. In other words, we
might well ask, "to whom has the Lord denied gifts that would
bring them back to him?" What child of God is their upon this
earth whom the Lord has denied those spiritual and temporal gifts
that would allow him/her to return to their Heavenly Father? The
answer, quite simply, is none. Every soul born upon this earth was
already one of the elect-a victor in the War in Heaven. Every soul is
born with the same destiny to return and live in a Heavenly Home,
For there is no respect of persons with God. Romans 2:11
The blessed man or woman, therefore, isn''t that soul who has
received the greatest amount from God, but rather, is that person who
recognizes God''s gifts in his/her life. The blessed soul
isn''t he who has received most, for we all receive according to
our capacity to receive. The blessed soul is that which recognizes
God''s love and His gifts.
Consider the Beatitudes in this context (Matthew 5:3-13):
· Blessed are the poor in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.
· Blessed are they that mourn: for they shall be comforted.
· Blessed are the meek: for they shall inherit the earth.
· Blessed are they which do hunger and thirst after righteousness: for
they shall be filled.
· Blessed are the merciful: for they shall obtain mercy.
· Blessed are the pure in heart: for they shall see God.
· Blessed are the peacemakers: for they shall be called the children
of God.
· Blessed are they which are persecuted for righteousness'' sake:
for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

shall say all manner of evil against you falsely, for my sake.
Rejoice, and be exceeding glad: for great is your reward in heaven:
for so persecuted they the prophets which were before you.
In each case, a person is recognized as blessed, not for something the
Lord has given them, but for something they''ve given back to the
Lord. In each case the person is blessed who has submitted to the
will of the Father (is poor in spirit, mourns, is meek, hungers after
righteousness, is merciful, pure in heart, a peacemaker, is
persecuted for righteousness'' sake, suffers for the Lord).
He''s blessed first for what he has submitted himself to, and
he''s promised blessings afterwards for the consequence of his
choice (obtains the kingdom of heaven, is comforted, inherits the
earth, is filled, obtains mercy, sees God, is called a Child of God,
obtains the kingdom of heaven, receives a great reward in Heaven.)
Thus, when the Lord pronounces Lehi blessed for his selfless actions,

home, and take an often-rebellious family into the wilderness to be

feeling God''s love in his life. Lehi is "blessed"
during the sacrifices he makes, because through these righteous acts

Conversely, we might add that any act of self-deprivation that
doesn''t allow us to feel God''s love at the moment of
submission probably isn''t a "blessing" to us.
We''re only blessed in sacrifice as it draws us closer to God and
allows us to feel his love for and through us.
